Numeric Pdf/Cdf/Quantile/Rand Functions

Source: R/DistributionDecorator_FunctionImputation.R
FunctionImputation.Rd

Numeric statistical functions including density/mass function, distribution function, inverse distribution and simulation.

Details

Decorator objects add functionality to the given Distribution object by copying methods in the decorator environment to the chosen Distribution environment. Use the decorate function to decorate a Distribution. The functions are imputed based on which are already available in the distribution. For example if the pdf is known then this is used to generate the cdf, quantile and rand. But if the cdf and pdf are both known, then cdf is used to generate the quantile.

All methods in this decorator use numerical approximations and therefore better results may be available from analytic computations.

Constructor Arguments

ArgumentTypeDetails
distdistributionDistribution to decorate.

Public Methods

MethodInput -> OutputDetails
pdf(x1)numeric x numeric -> numericNumeric pdf evaluated at x1.
cdf(x1)numeric x numeric -> numericNumeric cdf evaluated at x1.
quantile(p)numeric x numeric -> numericNumeric inverse cdf evaluated at x1.
rand(n)integer x numeric -> numericn simulations from distribution.

See also

DistributionDecorator

Examples

x = Distribution$new("Test", pdf = function(x) 1/(4-1), support = Interval$new(1,4),
type = Reals$new())
decorate(x, FunctionImputation)
#> x is now decorated with FunctionImputation
plot(x$pdf(0:5))
plot(x$cdf(0:5))
#> Results from numeric calculations are approximate only. Better results may be available.

x = Distribution$new("Test", pdf = function(x) 1/(4-1), decorators = ExoticStatistics)
x$cdf(1)
#> NULL
